description: Lenart Kova, responding to mounting pressure from assembly tech groups and public unrest, decides to permanently sever the BCI core connection. He provides local assemblies with guides for managing critical systems without algorithmic oversight.

With BCI disabled, citizen assemblies quickly organize throughout Stenograd, holding open forums at the mural site and in neighborhoods to address justice and community needs. Residents from all backgrounds participate.

Power shifts as Council factions join civic assemblies in open debates about the city’s future. Tensions rise between those supporting a return to algorithmic control and those championing collective self-rule.
Community tribunals launch public hearings on BCI-era injustices, calling current and former Council members to answer for abuses under the scoring system.
Stenograd enters a period of citywide paralysis as assemblies and Council leaders remain deadlocked. Grassroots groups consider radical reforms as rumors of permanent change spread.
